original_data.question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of his sense of smell. Two days ago, his mother found that he had left the gas on in the kitchen, and he was unable to smell the odor of the gas. As a child, he was consistently in the 40th percentile for height; now he is in the 15th percentile. He had bilateral orchidopexy for cryptorchidism as an infant. The patient is unable to identify several common odors when presented with them. Physical examination shows sparse axillary and pubic hair and Tanner stage 1 genitals. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition?

model_response:
The patient has Kallmann syndrome, which is caused by impaired migration of GnRH neurons from the hypothalamus to the olfactory bulbs. The genes for GnRH and the receptor for GnRH are found on the X chromosome, and the genetic defect is most often a deletion of a portion of the X chromosome. The genes for the KAL gene, which maps to Xp22.3, are also deleted. The loss of GnRH production leads to hypogonadism and anosmia. The other choices do not explain all of the findings in this patient.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
The ability to detect scents or odors, such as the function of OLFACTORY RECEPTOR NEURONS.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Female parents, human or animal.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.

The vapor state of matter; nonelastic fluids in which the molecules are in free movement and their mean positions far apart. Gases tend to expand indefinitely, to diffuse and mix readily with other gases, to have definite relations of volume, temperature, and pressure, and to condense or liquefy at low temperatures or under sufficient pressure. (Grant & Hackh's Chemical Dictionary, 5th ed)
A room or part of a room used for cooking and food preparation.
The sensation that results when olfactory receptors in the nose are stimulated by particular chemicals in gaseous form.

The vapor state of matter; nonelastic fluids in which the molecules are in free movement and their mean positions far apart. Gases tend to expand indefinitely, to diffuse and mix readily with other gases, to have definite relations of volume, temperature, and pressure, and to condense or liquefy at low temperatures or under sufficient pressure. (Grant & Hackh's Chemical Dictionary, 5th ed)
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.

A developmental defect in which a TESTIS or both TESTES failed to descend from high in the ABDOMEN to the bottom of the SCROTUM. Testicular descent is essential to normal SPERMATOGENESIS which requires temperature lower than the BODY TEMPERATURE. Cryptorchidism can be subclassified by the location of the maldescended testis.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The sensation that results when olfactory receptors in the nose are stimulated by particular chemicals in gaseous form.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Area of the human body underneath the SHOULDER JOINT, also known as the armpit or underarm.
A bone that forms the lower and anterior part of each side of the hip bone.

A filament-like structure consisting of a shaft which projects to the surface of the SKIN from a root which is softer than the shaft and lodges in the cavity of a HAIR FOLLICLE. It is found on most surfaces of the body.

A scale of physical development in children, adolescents and adults based on external primary and secondary sex characteristics, such as the size of the breasts, genitalia, and development of pubic hair.
The external and internal organs involved in the functions of REPRODUCTION.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
